Yet I could not have thought my Narciſſa would have triumphed over my misfortune. I could not have thought ſhe would ſo ſoon begin to upbraid and receive me coldly. Oh, woman! woman!

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Hoity, toity! what's the matter now? The man's ſeriouſly ſorrowful, as I live.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Cruel Narciſſa! what can I think of this?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p:
Think of it! Upon my word; I am full as much at loſs what to think of it as you are. Sure the people are all at croſs-purpoſes, or are eat up with the vapours this morning! My mama was here juſt now, and peeviſhly chid me forſooth, for being too kind to you: and now you come, in woful ſadneſs
to complain of my cruelty! What, in the name of conſiſtency, am I to do with you both?

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: I don't wonder, Narciſſa, that your mama hath changed her thoughts of me. A reverſe of fortune is with fathers and mothers a ſufficient motive for a reverſe of ſentiments. But can they, whoſe vows have been reciprocally exchang'd, whoſe hearts have been once united; can they, my Narciſſa, be ever divided from motives of ſordid intereſt? What tho' my father be dead, and, through dotard fondneſs has reduced his ſon to beggary, I have ſtill friends, real friends, able and willing to ſerve me.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Your father dead! reduced to beggary! I now underſtand you, Sir. [Aſide.] Diſingenuous mama! Theſe then were your reaſons for depreciating the character of my lover! [To Frederic.] Indeed, Sir, I beg your pardon, I had heard nothing of your father's death, nor of any change in your circumſtances: but I own the converſation I had juſt now with my mama, a good deal ſurprized me.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Then ſhe muſt have heard it.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: No doubt of it: and that accouuts for her behaviour.— [Aſide] She may find, however, that people may ſometimes be as much too reſerved as too open.— [To Frederic.] But can it really be, Sir, as you ſay?

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Too certainly; though I received the news myſelf from my father's agent but this morning, and came directly to impart it to you.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Was that prudent? to yourſelf at leaſt? was it impoſſible to conceal it from me 'till after our marriage?

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p:
It was Narciſſa, though no human being had known it but myſelf. Thoughtleſs and indiſcreet as I am, my heart is too faithful to you, and too juſt to the world, to ſuffer me to act the part of an impoſtor, a ſingle moment. Nay, I come now with a deſign to relinquiſh my pretenſions, 'till the happier circumſtances
of ſome future day might entitle me to aſpire to the heighth from which I am fallen.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: To give up your pretenſions, Mr. Melmoth! and was that ſo eaſy a taſk as to be readily reſolved on?

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: However raſhly reſolved, you have ſeen it was not ſo eaſy to be executed. For what have I done but ſolicit for that, which I came to reſign?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: And you would now marry me, notwithſtanding I may have fifteen thouſand pounds to my fortune, and you, as you ſay, not a farthing?

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Narciſſa!—

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Oh! you heſitate, do you?—To he ſure there is ſome little inequality of condition in the caſe: but to let you ſee that I am more aſpiring, I am ready to venture with you on the ſame terms.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: And is it poſſible you can be ſo good as to rate my merit above your fortune?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Nay, don't give me time to weigh one againſt the other. Money is heavy, and worth is light, you know: if you take me at my word, I ſhall keep it: but if I am left to cool and ponderate, I won't anſwer for myſelf.—Grave faces and good advice may have a ſtrange effect upon me. At preſent, I ſay, I'll venture with you.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Generous Narciſſa! But whether will you venture?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Any where:—to Scotland, if you are ſo raſh as to inſiſt upon it.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Spirited girl! charming Narciſſa! but when?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Now, this very day, as ſoon as you pleaſe. My mama has dealt diſingenuouſly by me. I will therefore beg leave of duty to ſtand aſide a little, 'till I pay the debt I owe to love and honour. If it be a fault, I ſhall truſt to her forgiveneſs this one time.— It is a fault one cannot make a practice of, you know.—So, come, let us go in, and concert proper meaſures for our expedition.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Charming creature! I'll accompany you to the world's end.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: O yes, I intend you ſhall, if we ſhould live to the end of the world.

div.head: SCENE III. Young Melmoth's Lodgings.
div.p: So, ſo, ſo. I have been playing with a ſeeming dead coal, that hath been all the while burning my fingers. A plague of theſe potential cauteries, ſay I.—Sir John Melmoth, it ſeems, is really dead; my young maſter is a beggar, and I may carry his wallet. Sic tranſit gloria mundi! Had I thought the old baronet really defunct, I ſhould not have been ſo pleaſant with the young one's circumſtances. But he is a deſerving youth; and though I am horribly diſappointed in my own expectations, I declare I am Ieſs ſorry for myſelf than for him.—What will become of him!—For my own part I am qualified to ſtruggle with the world.—Oh! here comes Sir Frederic—in a mighty good humour too! what the devil, ſure his father's not come to life again!

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Well, Syllogiſm, who hath called ſince. I have been out.—

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Nobody, Sir;—I expected to have been able to preſent your honour with at leaſt a hundred viſiting cards, full of compliments of condolance: but I find the world is not ſo impertinent; it civily chuſes to leave people under misfortunes to comfort themſelves.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p:
It is the improved mode of good manners, Syllogiſm, not to be troubleſome. You ſeem, however, to ſtand in need of conſolation! what's
the meaning of this? It is not above an hour or two ago ſince you braved the ſtorns of fortune with the fortitude of a ſtoick, and recommended patience to me with the eloquence of a Seneca.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; but, like Seneca too, I find I cou'd preach that to others which I cannot practice myſelf. But ſurely, Sir, I may conclude, from the pleaſantry of your preſent diſpoſition, that what you heard in the morning cannot be true!

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: True! Syllogiſm. How ſhou'd it be true, when you know you obſerved it to be impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Nay, but Sir, joking apart, if your father be dead, how do you intend to live, now he has diſinherited you?

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: I ſhall do the beſt: to ſupply my wants by induſtry. I ſhall find friends to put me in a way, and am only ſorry it will be out of my power to reward your ſidelity as it deſerves

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, make yourſelf eaſy about me; a philoſopher is eaſily provided for. Jacta eſt alea, Sir. When I have the misfortune to leave your ſervice, I devote myſelf immediately to that of the muſes.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: What, turn poet! then art thou condemned to be poor as long as thou liveſt. Why, the poverty of poets, man, is notorious; it hath been a hackneyed jeſt for ages.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it hath been hackneyed ſo long, that it is fairly worn out. When poets had no patrons but the great, the poor devils, ſure enough, were obliged to live upon little: but ſince the publick have taken them under their protection, a bard, like another man, may have two coats to his back, and every thing handſome about him.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: And yet, Syllogiſm, 'till the lawyers can decide the diſpute about literary property.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p:
I grant you, Sir, that a freehold on Parnaſſus does not intitle the poſſeſſor to vote for member of parliament; but let a man of genius once merit the
favour of the town, and he may levy contributions on it, whenever his affairs require it.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Levy contributions! is not that too arbitrary? I thought the convocation of criticks had ſomething to do in the ſyſtem of literary legiſlation.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, they are the lower houſe, and have the privilege of deciding in all money-matters. They hold their ſeſſions in the pit, at the repreſentation of every new play, and proceed directly to the conſideration of ways and means.—To be ſure, Sir, we cannot raiſe a ſhilling without the conſent of the houſe.—But if they approve the bill, they paſs it with a plaudit, and their generoſity is boundleſs.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Well, Syllogiſm, if you are obliged to go upon the town, I can only wiſh you ſucceſs: but perhaps you may be better provided for, yet: in the mean time, you muſt not leave me abruptly—I ſhall want your ſervice, for ſome time at leaſt, I am going a journey of three hundred miles an end; will you go with me, if I ſhould have occaſion for you?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Te duce Teucro, to the antipodes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Come this way then, you muſt take a let er for me to Narciſſa.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Of leave, I ſuppoſe, ah! poor girl! ſhe'll be diſappointed too! Oh! 'tis a bitter buſineſs.

div.head: SCENE IV. Colonel Camply's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter General Melmoth and Colonel Camply.

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: So then I find, colonel, you are engaged in a matrimonial expedition as well as my kinſman.— Well, I wiſh you ſucceſs, and if you need my aſſiſtance, command me.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p:
I thank you, general, and hope ere long to be able to return the compliment. Come, come,
when you have recovered your ſpirits a little, we ſhall have you looking out for a wife as well as we younger folks.

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: Ah! my dear colonel!

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Ah! my dear colonel! with a ſigh too! I have hit the mark then, general? What did you leave your heart in India? or hath a ſudden conqueſt been made of it ſince your arrival in Europe?

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: Neither, Camply. I was married many years ago, and was too unhappy in that ſtate, ever to think of entering into it again, even if I knew myſelf at liberty.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: I never heard you had been married, general.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Yes, colonel, when I went over to India, I left a wife and infant daughter in England behind me.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: And are they living?

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: Alas! heaven knows! I have heard nothing of them for years, except from the very man, of whom being abſurdly jealous, I thought I had killed.—He came over with our troops ſome time ago to Bengal, and convinced me by a number of corroborating circumſtances, that I had injured both him and my wife; but to my ſorrow, he could give me no farther information of her.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: How fruitleſs then was that!

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: Fruitleſs as unhappy! for though my heart was ſomething lighter, from knowing he had recovered of the wounds I had given him; yet I ſhou'd have much eaſier ſupported the reflection of having killed an adulterer, than that of having injured, abandoned, and perhaps ultimately deſtroyed, am innocent wife and daughter.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: But why deſtroyed? from this relation it is not impoſſible they may ſtill be living.

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p:
I dare not flatter myſelf with ſuch a ſuggeſtion. Nay, I hardly know whether I ought to wiſh it true: for if ſhe lives, muſt ſhe not long ſince have
transferred that heart to anothet which I ſo unjuſtly ſuſpected, ſo cruelly ſlighted?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: But what ſucceſs has attended your enquiries ſince?

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: None; though I have made every enquiry the diſtance of time and place would admit.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Perhaps in your long abſence, thinking you were dead, ſhe may have married again; and thus, by her change of name, have eluded your reſearches.

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: If it be ſo, I will be no intruder on her happineſs.—I will therefore carry on my future ſearch in perſon; that, if I ſhould ſucceed in it, I may be enabled to act as circumſtances ſhall determine. But what a taſk! How dreadful is't to ſeek that which we hope, and yet we fear, to find! Though to be certain even of what we fear, is better far than labouring ſtill in doubt.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Mr. Melmoth, Sir, deſires to know if your honour is alone.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Your kinſman, general, —Shall he come up?

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: By all means. He may have ſome buſineſs with you; I'll retire into your ſtudy till you have done with him; you know I have my reaſons for declining to ſee him at preſent.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: How unlucky is this!—I muſt not tell Melmoth who is ſo near; and yet, if I don't, 'tis ten to one he'll ſay ſome extravagant thing or other; which, if over-heard, may give the general no good opinion of him. I wiſh my old friend were at Bengal again only for one half hour, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: My dear colonel, how is it?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Nay, how is it with you? You ſeem in raptures, and it is not three hours ago ſince I left you in a ſtate of deſpondency.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Ay, you grave rogue, you—you ſtare to ſee a young fellow dejected at his ill luck in the morning, intoxicated with his good fortune before noon. But Narciſſa's my own, my boy.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Who doubted it?

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: No; it wou'd have been a ſacrilege to doubt it.—So that as to my father—

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Nay, but Mr. Melmoth, nothing againſt your father I beg of you— [Aſide.] The general will certainly overhear him.—[To Melmoth.] Well, but you did not tell Narciſſa of your being diſinherited!

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Did not I?—But I did. I told her the whole ſtory.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: The deuce you did!

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Without omitting a ſingle circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: And—and—and— [Aſide.] Egad, I believe I had better aſk him no more queſtions—He ſeems in a humour to ſay any thing.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: And—and—and—what a plague do you mean by your and—and—and?—Why do you look ſo confoundedly ſerious? What the devil is the matter with you?—Ah, colonel! colonel! if you did but know all!

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Nay, but I don't deſire to know all— [Aſide.] This ſpark's going to ſay ſome wild thing or other, now.

sp.speaker: Y.
sp.p: Nay but you ſhall know all; for I came on purpoſe to tell you.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Well then, ſome other time.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: No, no other time will do: for I intend to be in Scotland by to morrow night, if poſſible.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: In Scotland!

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Ay, I am going off with Narciſſa to Scotland, and am come to borrow your chaiſe, if you'll lend it me.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: And what are you going to do there?

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! There's a queſtion! I thought every body knew what penny-leſs young fellows took girls of fortune to Scotland for.—

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Well, but—

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Nay, nay, will you lend me your chaiſe? I'll tell you more of the affair by and by—I ſhall want a couple of your ſervants, too; as, for reaſons of ſtate, I ſhall take none of my own with me.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Yes, if I am to ſee you again—[Aſide.] any thing to get rid of you now— [To Melmoth.] but I ſhall certainly ſee you again before you go.—

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Certainly.—Certainly.

To Scotland! egad, Narciſſa has an enterprizing ſpirit. If the general hath overheard nothing of our converſation, I muſt communicate this piece of intelligence to him; it may perhaps induce him to vary his plan of operation, and ſave them the trouble of the journey.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: So, colonel, your young friend hath ſoon left you.—I thought I heard high words within.— I hope no new cauſe of diſcontent?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir; quite the reverſe. Your lively kinſman is now as much elated with joy, as he was in the morning depreſſed with ſorrow.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: How ſo? He can have heard nothing, ſure, of the real ſtate of his circumſtances!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Nothing at all; but it ſeems he hath informed his miſtreſs of his ſuppoſed loſs of his father's fortune; and ſhe, like a generous girl, hath agreed to give him her own inſtead of it.

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: They are juſt going to ſet off for Scotland; he came to borrow my chaiſe.

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: And you ſhall lend it them, or I will clap ſix horſes to my own travelling coach, and that ſhall convey them. I like their ſpirit, and would encourage their expedition, were the young lady ev'n my own daughter.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Nay, but, general, why let them take ſo unneceſſary a ſtep?—They will certainly be better pleaſed, if you ſhould diſcover Mr. Melmoth's real ſituation, and prevent them.

sp.speaker: G. Melm.
sp.p: I know not that. No, let them a while enjoy the ſatisfaction they feel in their mutual love and gratitude. There is more pleaſure in the diſplay of true generoſity, than in the poſſeſſion of mines of wealth. Let them proceed, therefore, on their journey. —I warrant it will be a pleaſant one.—In the mean time, however, if it be neceſſary, I'll endeavour to reconcile the young lady's relations to the conſequences of it.—But come, I called to take you home to dinner with me; we will there toaſt the young couple, and drink ſucceſs to their ſpirited enterprize.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: So, Mr. Syllogiſm, you are going to have old doings at your houſe, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: No, no, Mrs. Sift, our old doings won't do any longer; we muſt have new doings now, if we intend to keep doing at all.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: What do you mean, Mr. Syllogiſm?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Nay, what do you mean, Mrs. Sift, if you come to that?

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Mean! why rejoicings, entertainments, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Rejoicings! entertainments!— [Aſide.]—O, the jade has heard of our misfortune I find, and has a mind to be merry with it.— [To Sift.]—You are pleaſed to banter, I ſee, Mrs. Sift.—Pray what ſhould we rejoice at?

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Rejoice at! why, the arrival of Mr. Melmoth's father from the Indies—Have you not expected him any time theſe ſix months?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Oh, yes; and he ſet out from thence, it ſeems, near a twelve month ago; but which road he took, or whether he is arrived at his journey's end, is at preſent a little problematical!

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p:
Problematical! I am ſure you ſcholars, Mr. Syllogiſm, are very pragmatical. Will you perſuade
me I did not hear the bells ring for him this morning?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: The bells ring for him! O lud! only think of tolling the bell at Bath for a man who died at Bengal!

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Dead! Sir! What would you inſinuate?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: What you know, I find, as well as I, and therefore I may venture to tell you.—My old maſter is dead, and hath left my young one nothing to live upon.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Mr. Syllogiſm, I ſee you have a mind to banter me now; but come, to buſineſs. You have brought ſomething for Narciſſa, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Yes, I have got a letter for her.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.stage: —[Takes the letter, turns it about, and holds it up to the light.]
sp.p: —Why there's no reading this letter without opening it!

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: What do you think it is ſealed up for, but to hinder you?

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Pooh! I would not give a farthing to carry ſuch letters. Sealed! What did you never open a letter without breaking the ſeal? Did you never take off the impreſſion on wax, nor coax it with a hot tobacco pipe?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: No, Mrs. Sift, they are arts I have not been bred to.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Well, I have done it an hundred times, who was never bred to the arts at all: though I remember I once loſt the beſt place I ever had in my life, for breaking open a letter, and ſealing it up again with my thimble.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: And deſervedly.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Yes, I paid for my peeping that time, it's true; but I ſhould have done it, had I been to die for it. I am aſtoniſhed to think how any body can have ſo little curioſity, as not to long to know every thing that other people want to keep from them.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: I would as ſoon put my hand into my maſter's purſe, as pry into his ſecrets; and think a ſervant deſerves to be hanged as much for the one as the other.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: That is, if it be done with intent to betray them, Mr. Syllogiſm; but otherwiſe—and yet, to be ſure, one does ſometimes do a deal of miſchief by getting into ſecrets by halves; but that is the fault of one's maſters and miſtreſſes, you know, in not truſting us with the whole.—You will not pretend to tell me, however, that you have no curioſity to know your maſter's buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Faith I have no curioſity to know more than he thinks proper to intruſt me with. I have plague and trouble enough with that; if I knew leſs, I ſhould live a much eaſier life: for what between his money-matters and thoſe of his miſtreſs, which you know, Sift, are both tickliſh affairs, I have but a very troubleſome time on't.
sp.stage: [While Syllogiſm is ſpeaking, Sift is looking at the letter, and turning it about in her hand.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: There muſt be ſomething very curious, Syllogiſm, in this letter. It is doubled into ſo many pleats, and folded up as carefully as the Welch-man's guinea—there is certainly ſomething choice in it.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Ay, all love I ſuppoſe, Sift.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Love! eh!—that's choice ſtuff, to be ſure! —Well, I ſee the direction.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: And you'll deliver it ſafely—you underſtand me—you need not be at the trouble of quartering my maſter's coat of arms with the milliner's.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: O! the thimble! no, upon my honour.—

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: You ſee the creſt is a lion rampant, beware of the top of your middle finger.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Nay, but when I ſay upon my honour, Mr. Syllogiſm.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p:
I beg your honour's pardon, Madam. To be ſure, after having ſo frankly confeſſed its influence over your curioſity in theſe caſes, it wou'd be
cruel to diſtruſt you — [Aſide as he goes out.] If I had my letter again however, I would as ſoon leave it with the printer of the Public Advertiſer.

They think they are mighty cloſe here—It is written with lemon juice, ſurely!—Well I have a trick for that; my miſtreſs ſhan't ſet me upon the enquiry for nothing I am too good a ſervant for that too— Ha! our young ladies coming this way!—I am determined to have another peep at it, be the conſequence what it will. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Well, really Sophia, this is ſomething extraordinary that you ſhou'd affect to tutor me, for diſobedience to my mama, in the preference I give to Mr. Melmoth: hath not ſhe, 'till this very day, always approved of his addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Therefore I am afraid, Narciſſa, ſhe has ſome better reaſons for her ſudden change of behaviour than you are aware of: at leaſt I ſhou'd be for coming to a farther explanation with her before I took ſo irretrievable a ſtep as you are going inconſiderately to do.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Oh! my dear, we ſhall take a great many ſteps before we get to Scotland. We ſhall not be acroſs the Tweed ſo ſoon as we might be at the next pariſh church. I ſhall have time to conſider of it again and again, therefore, before the buſineſs is done yet.—Nay, I can aſſure you that even when we get there, if I ſhou'd not happen to be perfectly of the opinion I am in at preſent, we may come back again no wiſer than we ſet out. If the matrimonial apparatus does not wear a very agreeable aſpect—if Meſs-John does not put on one of his beſt faces, and his cleaneſt band;—or—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, but be ſerious.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Well, I am: and ſay as I did before, that if there were really any thing wrong in what I am going to do, you ſhou'd be the laſt perſon in the world, my dear Sophy, to diſſuade me from it.

sp.speaker: Sopht
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Becauſe I ſhould never liſten to a lecture on diſobedience from one as diſobedient as myſelf.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: How! cannot I entertain a proper regard for colonel Camply, without incurring the guilt of diſobedience? I don't intend to run away with him, or even to marry him, without my father's conſent.

sp.speaker: Narc
sp.p: Not unleſs he refuſes to give it you; there is no occaſion for't, my dear. But if by a proper regard, you mean that the colonel is in poſſeſſion of your heart, I warrant your hand will ſoon follow. And, tho' you may want courage to ſcamper away to the North, before you come of age, you may only have juſt patience enough to ſtay in the South 'till you do; when we ſhall find you ſneaking into the back-door of Walbrook-church, or St. Swithins, to commit the like horrid ſin of diſobedience.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I find, my dear, there is no talking to you on this ſubject: ſo, like a naughty girl, you muſt go on your own way.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: And you, like a naughty girl, Sophy, wou'd go my way too, if you dar'd.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: The devil take the inventors of ſealing-wax, and inviſible ink;—I can pick nothing out of this letter— ſo I think may as well give it to my young miſtreſs. If ſhe can read it, I may poſſibly pick ſomething of it out of her, and that will do as well.—A letter for you, Madam

sp.speaker: Narc
sp.p: From Mr. Melmoth!

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: You will excuſe me, Sophy, I muſt go and read my billet-doux; it may poſſibly require an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: So!—now for a peep over the left ſhoulder.—Let the writing be but any how viſible, and if young madam reads any more of it than I, why then, I am grown ſhortſighted—that's all.

Was ever any thing ſo determinedly inconſiderate? —and yet Narciſſa does not want for prudence, when the vivacity of her temper will ſuffer her to make uſe of it.—I wiſh I cou'd any how prevent this raſh expedition, without betraying the confidence ſhe has placed in me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Urge this affair no farther, Furnival. I can be of no ſervice to you in it.—I have conſulted my heart, and find it repugnant to all my ſentiments. The love I bear Narciſſa, and the regard due to my own honour; both forbid it.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Give me leave to ſay, my lord, your ſcruples are too refined for a man ſo well acquainted with the world.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, barriſter, I know the world too well to ſacrifice ſo much of my own happineſs, either to its pleaſures or opinions, as I have done.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: But if your lordſhip has no hopes of Narciſſa, what objection can be made to your repairing your fortune by marrying another? Surely, my lord, neither the laws of love or honour forbid this!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Perhaps not— but I feel an invincible reluctance to the making my addreſſes elſewhere. It is
true; Narciſſa herſelf gives me no encouragement; but her mother is ſtill my friend, and affords me hopes that ſomething may turn out in my favour: I have even juſt now received a meſſage from her, deſiring to ſee me in the evening, on particular buſineſs.— Who knows what may have happened? But be it as it may, I cannot reſolve to devote myſelf to another, 'till it be impoſſible for Narciſſa to be mine.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: And your lordſhip is determined to decline the obliging offers of Mr. alderman Lombard, with regard to the money matters I was ſpeaking of?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If they are made on a preſumption that I ſhall ſerve him where I have neither the power nor inclination.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: I am heartily ſorry for it, my lord; as this is not the way to pay off the mortgage on your eſtate.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Then it muſt remain unpaid, barriſter, 'till a more honourable method offers for its diſcharge.

His lordſhip is in one of his moral moods to day. —I muſt reſume the ſubject at a gayer moment.— And yet I'm half afraid he's loſt.—Theſe partial attachments to the ſex are the ruin of many a noble ſpirit. While he was only a general lover, he was the moſt enterprizing genius on the turf.—But now—'Tis ſtrange; but we ſometimes find it in the power of one virtuous woman to reform in a few months what the libertine part of both ſexes have been labouring to corrupt for years.—Theſe modeſt wenches make as many converts as the methodiſt parſons—Whom have we here?—the very ladies in queſtion, as I live!—and engaged in earneſt diſcourſe!—It may be worth liſtening to— I have an excellent knack of hearing at a diſtance. [Retires.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And you are really determined, Narciſſa, to put this wild ſcheme in execution.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Poſitively, my dear Sophia.—I ſhall not break my word with Mr. Melmoth, if he keep his with me. We are to have your colonel's chaiſe waiting for us at the town's end. I ſhall juſt go to the rooms with you for form's ſake, and ſee you ſet in for cards, and then vaniſh; ſlip into a chair, and be with my ſpark in a twinkling: leaving you, my dear, or your colonel, to make the beſt apology you can for me to my mama.—I have left a ſhort one indeed myſelf in a letter ſhe will find on her return in the evening.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: As you have made me your confident, my dear, I ſhall not betray you. But I cannot ſay I approve of this ſtep. Indeed I really think it unneceſſary. I am certain your mama might be brought to give her conſent to your marriage.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Nay then there is the leſs harm, my dear, in going to be married without it. If ſhe has no objections, you know, but what might be removed by ſolicitation, the ſolicitation would be merely a matter of form, a piece of childiſh ceremony.—Beſides, my dear Sophy, to anſwer all your petty ſcruples about diſobedience at once, I am determined on the thing preciſely, becauſe I would not be diſobedient.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ay; make that out, Narciſſa.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p:
Very plainly.—My mama has not yet poſitively told me ſhe would not have me marry Mr. Melmoth:—on the contrary, ſhe has hitherto encouraged his addreſſes: but as I ſhrewdly ſuſpect ſhe might tell me ſo in plain terms the next time we converſe on the ſubject, I don't intend to give her an opportunity of laying me under any ſuch injunction. —Becauſe, in that caſe, you know, it would be
downright diſobedience to act directly againſt her poſitive commands.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Well; for ſuch a mad-cap, thou art certainly a very extraordinary caſuiſt.—So joy go with you.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: I warrant it will. I only wiſh we may bring it back again; and make it laſt as long as the wedding ring and the parſon's benizon hold us together. —So come along.

So, ſo, ſo—Here's an affair broke out!— What will his ſcrupulous lordſhip ſay to this?— Egad, we juſt nicked the time. The bird is feathered, and juſt on the wing. But the lime and twigs ſhall be ready, my dear. No, no, my pretty flutterer, you muſt not take flight, and leave us yet, neither.—What if I worked by ſtratagem, and entrapped my little lapwing in her own ſnare!— Her chairmen may poſſibly be prevailed on to miſtake the place of rendezvous.—If I can but decoy her to his lordſhip's apartments, he may ſet her at liberty himſelf, if he chuſes it. It is a pretty Canary-bird, and would become a gilt cage mightily.

div.head: SCENE III. Mrs. Mildmay's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Mildmay, (with an open letter in her hand) followed by Sift and Suſan.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: To Scotland! and with young Melmoth—raſh, unadviſed girl!—Diſpatch ſomebody to colonel Camply. Tell him I muſt ſpeak with him inſtantly, on buſineſs of the utmoſt cenſequence.

sp.speaker: Suſan.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Oh! Narciſſa!

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: But why, Madam, ſhould you make yourſelf ſo very uneaſy? Mr. Melmoth is a worthy young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Talk not to me of his worth—

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: And the young people, heaven bleſs them! were paſſionately fond of one another.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Mild. Ah! too paſſionately—

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Then Mr. Melmoth is—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: You know not what he is, Sift: nor can I tell you.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My lord Courtly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Shew him up.

div.p: See that colonel Camply be found immediately, Sift. [Exit Sift.
Oh! my lord, I am the moſt terrified and diſtreſſed of women. The delight of my heart, the wiſh of yours, my darling Narciſſa—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Narciſſa! what of Narciſſa, Madam? you alarm me beyond expreſſion. Surely no accident—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Yes. the moſt dreadful accident!— in the moſt ſudden and unexpected manner is ſhe gone off with young Melmoth for Scotland.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Then are my hopes at an end.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Not ſo, my lord, if their deſign be prevented. They cannot be got far as yet. Your lordſhip will aſſiſt me in immediately purſuing them.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
If my preventing Narciſſa's marriage with Mr. Melmoth, might induce her to beſtow her heart on me, Madam, you might command me: but I fear hearts are not to be transferred, and ſhe has now
given a ſufficient proof on whom ſhe has freely beſtowed hers. I cannot therefore think of robbing another of what he has ſo good a right to poſſeſs, becauſe I had not the merit of a ſucceſsful rival.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Alas, my lord, Mr. Melmoth can be no rival.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You flattered me indeed, Madam, with the diſcovery of a circumſtance in my favour.

sp.speaker: Mrs Mild.
sp.p: It is this very circumſtance, my lord, that aggravates my preſent diſtreſſes; as I now fear, that, inſtead of contributing to your happineſs, it will only tend to my miſery.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What is it then, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: In the preſent ſituation of things, my lord, I cannot refuſe to impart it to you; though I have reaſon for concealing it a while from all the world beſides.—Mr. Melmoth is—Narciſſa's brother.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Narciſſa's brother!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: By the moſt providential means, I this day diſcovered it; therefore, my lord—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, if that be the caſe;—but are you certain I

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Moſt certain;—therefore make no delay. Narciſſa cannot be Mr. Melmoth's; ſhe may be yours, and be happy.—All depends on the moment.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Then depend on't, Madam, I will give you a good account of my time. Your ſervants will aſſiſt me to procure the means of purſuit, and be aſſured you ſhall ſpeedily hear from me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: One thing more, my lord. If either perſuaſion or force may effect their return, let the circumſtance of their affinity be as yet kept a ſecret from them.— I have particular reaſons for it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I ſhall obey your commands, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p:
Who waits there? John! Thomas! attend upon his lordſhip.—Well, now I am ſomething eaſier. The inconſiderate ſugitives will be
overtaken. Inconſiderate indeed! but alas, had it been otherwiſe, how innocent had been their crime! Yet happy is it, that, through all the various accidents of life, there is an over-ruling providence, which often preſerves us from the ill conſequences even of our own indiſcretions.

div.head: SCENE IV. A Street near Lord Courtly's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Furnival, diſguiſed in a Cloak, followed by a chair, with the curtains drawn.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: This way, Patrick.— [In a low voice, and exit. 1ſt Chairm. Which way your honour pleaſes. 2d Chairm. Ay, I thought young madam would not be after going out of town to night.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: What a round-about way have theſe fellows taken! but I was only bid to follow them, and and ſo, ite, pre, ſequar.— [Going off, ſtops ſhort.]— Hey day! they turn into a houſe!—Sure that is more than we bargained for.—I hope there is no miſtake here.—Drinking to beſure depreſſes the judgment, though it elevates the imagination: if potation, however, deprives a man of his diſcretion, it gives him courage to face the peril it leads him into. Not that I am ſo tipſy as to be very valiant neither, though I did get rather a cup too much in waiting, ere the dog-trotting ſcoundrels were put in motion.—But I have claſſical authority for taking a chearful glaſs in the evening, Ut vites poenam de polibus incipe caenam.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Syllogiſm! What are you doing here? Where is Narciſſa? Did not I bid you watch her coming out of the rooms, and follow her chair?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: You did, Sir, and ſo I have. It is juſt gone into that houſe.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Into a houſe! you muſt have miſtaken ſome other chair for her's. What a blockhead! why you're half drunk;—you can't ſee.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, it is no deception; as ſure as you ſtand there, I ſaw the chair, that brought Narciſſa from the rooms, go into that houſe.

sp.speaker: E. Melm.
sp.p: Is't poſſible! For heaven's ſake who lives there?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Why, Sir, that I was poſing myſelf about, when you came in.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: As I live, lord Courtly's old lodgings.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and now I recollect, I believe his new ones too. I think I ſaw ſome of his ſervants about the door to-day.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Was ſhe brought hither by her own direction?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I can't tell; but it certainly muſt be with her own conſent, or otherwiſe ſhe would have prevented it.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: And why did not you?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, you know my orders were only to ſee the chair ſafe where it was carried to, and there to leave it. So, Sir, I walked a chalk after it, as ſtill as a mouſe all the way.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: But you knew whither it was going, why did not you make the fellows keep ſtrait forward.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I found it a little difficult to keep quite ſtrait forward myſelf. Beſides, Sir, I thought theſe fellows muſt know their way about the town better than I did.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: What can be the meaning of this? Sure Narciſſa does not intend to jilt me! to give her hand to lord Courtly after all! O no! that is impoſſible.

div.stage: [Goes out at the ſide of the ſcene, looking up at the houſe.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Impoſſible! ah, Sir! ſo you ſaid, you know, when you heard of your father's death; but, under correction, Sir, it is juſt as poſſible for a young lady to give away her heart, as for an old gentleman to give up the ghoſt.—Inconſtancy and intemperance are both fatal in their conſequences;— [Hicups]—But then thoſe conſequences are ſo very common, that there are matches broke off, and funerals performed to every part of England daily; and for that matter, Sir, under correction—

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Ha! the door opens! ſtand back, Syllogiſm, ſomebody is coming.

div.stage: [They retire to the back of the ſcenes.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: —I inſiſt upon going, Sir; let go my hand, Sir; What is the meaning of this inſolence?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: You muſt not riſk the danger, Madam, of going at this time of night alone.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: I can be no where in ſo much danger as in ſtaying with you.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Nay, but Mr. Melmoth will be here immediately, Madam.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: He is here already, Sir.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Melmoth what a villainous trick has been play'd us?

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how came this lady here? and to what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: You ſhou'd ask the one of the chairmen who brought her, Sir; and the other of the lady who doubtleſs directed them.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p:
Come, Sir, no ſhuffling. How came you to mention my name, as a pretence for detaining
her?—Expect to be called to a ſevere account for this piece of treachery.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, my deſign was merely to oblige my friend lord Courtly, in preventing the lady's elopement.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: And what right had either you or he, Sir, to pry into, or controul her actions?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I ſhall not enter into the matter of right, as the lady has nothing to complain of, but being prevented committing an act of diſobedience.— But, yonder I ſee comes my lord himſelf with the ſervants of the family, to conduct the young lady home.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Confuſion! how cou'd we be thus betray'd?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Betray'd indeed! and by what infamous means! I did not think my lord Courtly cou'd have deſcended to ſuch baſeneſs, or my mama have abetted it. But they ſhall reap no advantage from the ſucceſs of it.—Lead the way, Mr. Melmoth, and I'll follow you through all oppoſition.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Syllogiſm, ſtand to your arms.—

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and I'll make any body elſe ſtand too, or fall, that offers to moleſt you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ha; Narciſſa! and Mr. Melmoth! fortunate encounter.— [To the ſervants.] Stand back till you are called for.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Perhaps not ſo fortunate as you imagine, my lord.—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: For you I am ſure it is: and as for myſelf, the ſervice I may do you both, will at leaſt entitle me to your gratitude.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: If you are ſerious, my lord, your abſurdity borders on impertinence; if you mean to be ironical you are extremely ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I flatter myſelf, Madam, you will ſoon think otherwiſe; and that however unſucceſsful I have hitherto been, I ſhall, for my aſſiduity to night, be rewarded with your good opinion.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Indeed, my lord, you are egregiouſly miſtaken. What extravagance! To employ your baſe paraſite to decoy me to your houſe, and flatter yourſelf to obtain my good opinion of it. Indeed, indeed, my lord, this is one of the groſſeſt inſtances of ſelf-adulation I ever met with.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Decoy you to my houſe, Madam! I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam!— [To Narciſſa.] I can anſwer for his lordſhip's innocence in that particular.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we ſhall certainly take your word for his innocence.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Be prepared, Sir, to anſwer for your own —But come, Narciſſa, — [offering to go] we loſe time.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Let me intreat you not to be too precipitate. Mrs. Mildmay entreats, nay inſiſts that you will proceed no farther without conſulting your friends.—

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: One of which, I preſume, is to be your lordſhip. No, no, my lord, we have loſt too much time by your contrivance already.—Therefore ſtand aſide, if you pleaſe.—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Nay, but for your own ſakes.—

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: For our own ſakes, my lord, or yours! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: This is no place to enforce my own pretenions: I act now only in obedience to Mrs. Mildmay; who charged me, to ſay, that all laws human and divine, oppoſe your union.

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: Very pathetic indeed, my lord! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: I muſt ſecond this motion.— [to young Melmoth.] Yes, Sir, and as the lady is a minor, the laws of England too—

sp.speaker: Y.Melm.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, we ſhall not venture to break the laws of England, 'till we get into Scotland: ſo that you may ſpare your rhetorick.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: On my honour, Madam, you cannot be the wife of Mr. Melmoth.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: But I ſuppoſe I might be your's, my lord, if I aſpired to that dignity; and ſo in return for your extraordinary friendſhip I promiſe you, that when I find I cannot be Mr. Melmoth's, I will give my hand to your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If I ſhould take you at your word, Madam.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: I will certainly keep it, and ſo now, I hope, you are ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But Narciſſa!

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant, my lord.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Mr. Melmoth!

sp.speaker: Y. Melm.
sp.p: My lord, your moſt obedient.—Come Narciſſa, we'll take this way—poor lord Courtly! Ha, ha, ha! [Exit young Melmoth and Narciſſa.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Madneſs and folly! How raſh and reſolute! At all hazard they muſt be prevented. Mrs. Mildmay muſt unfold the ſecret.—Advance there—Barriſter, purſue and detain them till I return with the lady's mother.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Follow me.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Mr. Barriſter, not a ſtep farther, if you pleaſe—and you, gentlemen, keep back I charge you, as you ſet a ſtore by your reſpective pericraniums.— [Brandiſhing his endgel, the ſevents make a ſhew of reſiſting with their ſticks.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: What does the fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: I'll ſhew you that, Mr. Lawyer. [Throwing open his great coat, and ſhewing a blunderbuſs ſlung over his ſhoulders.] Do you ſee this curious piece of caſuiſtry? it contains very weighty reaſons againſt you I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: A blunderbuſs loaded with ſlugs, I ſuppoſe a powerful way of arguing indeed!

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: This, Sir, is the ultima ratio dialectici, and and is the moſt effectual argumentum ad hominem in the whole ſyſtem of logic.

div.stage: [Preſents the piece to the ſervants, who ſtart back.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Is the man mad, or drunk?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Be which he will, Sir, we had better retire, for fear of miſchief.

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, you had better take good advice, and retire, for fear of miſchief.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Wou'd the wretch commit murder?

sp.speaker: Syllog.
sp.p: Not downright murdrum, Mr. Barriſter, as you wou'd call it; but being a little inebriated, one's hand is liable to ſhake, and this damned trigger here has no catch. [Plays with the lock of the piece, with the mouth turned towards Furnival.] Beſides, Sir, I am placed here upon duty; and by all the rules of war and logic, if you proceed vi et armis, I muſt oppoſe you by the ſame mode of ratiocination; therefore give up the point, ye ſcoundrels, [Turning round, and preſenting the piece at the ſervants] or I will let fly ſuch a ſhower of majors and minors among you, that ſhall make you tremble for the conſequences.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: What, all gone! then I think I may as well withdraw my plea too. His lordſhip will certainly be nonſuited. [Sneaks off.

So! the enemy hath made his retreat, and the day's my own. Egad I think I have diſplayed my prowiſs pretty well here.—I hope by this time my general hath carried off the ſpoils of the field, and then I ſhall have nothing to do but make an end of my ſupper, and ſing Te deum for the victory— with a health to the King.—Tol de rol, tol de rol.—

div.stage: [Shoulders his blunderbuſs and ſtruts off, ſinging the tune of the Belleiſle march.

div.head: SCENE the Parade.
div.stage: Enter general Melmoth and colonel Camply.

sp.speaker: General Melmoth.
sp.p: THAT was unlucky, colonel—and ſo the young folks were intercepted in their flight.

sp.speaker: G. Camp.
sp.p: By the lady's mother, Sir; who, being early informed of their intention, was by the aid and advice of lord Courtly at the place of rendezvous before they ſet off. For my own part, apprehenſive that my aſſiſtance would be called for, I purpoſely kept out of the way.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: And how takes my kinſman his rival's interpoſition in this affair? Have you ſeen him to day?

sp.speaker: C. Cam.
sp.p: Juſt now; and horribly mortified at his diſappointment, I aſſure you. He had juſt diſpatch'd a note to lord Courtly.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: A challenge! ha! colonel!—a mettled ſpark! But we muſt have no fighting, if it can be decently prevented: the conſequences may be fatal.

sp.speaker: C. Cam.
sp.p: I don't ſee how Mr. Melmoth can recede, general; he muſt call his lordſhip to account for his laſt night's miſbehaviour.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p:
Well, but you may be his ſecond, colonel, and prolong the ceremonials 'till I have had ſome talk with the young lady's mother. I promiſed yeſterday to endeavour to conciliate matters with her relations, had ſhe gone off with my kinſman to Scotland;
I can do no leſs than try how far my influence may extend now. If Mrs. Mildmay's objections to young Melmoth be merely founded on his ſuppoſed want of fortune, they are readily obviated; and if lord Courtly be as you ſay, a man of ſenſe and principle, he will give up the point; and no longer endeavour to divide two young people, whoſe hearts ſeem form'd for each other. O! here comes Mr. Alderman Lombard.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: I had a meeting with him laſt night, to ſettle the affair of my executorſhip; when I took an opportunity to mention yours with his daughter, Sophia; as alſo your electioneering buſineſs; in which he does not meet with the encouragement he expected; ſo that you may not find him ſo refractory as you imagined.—I have taken ſome ſteps towards your reconciliation.

sp.speaker: C. Cam.
sp.p: This is ſo kind and obliging in you, general—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p:
Nay, no compliments, my dear colonel; while dead to family connexions myſelf, I live but for the ſervice of my friends. Enter alderman Lombard.
Good-morrow, Mr. Alderman.—

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: Good-morrow to you, general.—(to Camply) your humble ſervant, Sir.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Colonel Camply, Mr. Lombard, a gentleman extremely deſirous of a more intimate acquaintance with you.

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: I know it, Sir.—Tho' a ſtranger to his perſon, I am none to his name, and pretenſions.—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: To both which, Sir, I hope you will ſoon be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: I don't know that, Sir.—You ſet up for a borough, it ſeems, that I want to get for myſelf.

sp.speaker: C. Cam.
sp.p: I do, Sir, at the general requeſt of the conſtituents.

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: And you put up for a daughter too, whom perhaps I have a mind to keep to myſelf.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: What, if you can diſpoſe of her to advantage, and make her happy in a good huſband, Mr. Lombard! No, no. I dare ſay you are too good a father for that.

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure, general, if I could promote her happineſs, and my influence in the borough at the ſame time—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Both which I dare ſay you will, in conciliating matters with my friend, the colonel. You own, Mr. Lombard, the force of the arguments I made uſe of laſt night.—I ſhall now, therefore, leave the diſcuſſion of the matter to yourſelves; having ſome buſineſs of conſequence to diſpatch elſewhere. Mr. Lombard, your moſt obedient.—

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: General, your ſervant.—Well, young gentleman, what is it you have to propoſe?

sp.speaker: C. Cam.
sp.p: Sir, if you pleaſe to ſtep to my lodging, we may there talk the matter over a little.

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: Look'ye, Sir, if you love my daughter, you muſt give up the borough.

sp.speaker: C. Cam.
sp.p: Sir, I have the higheſt regard for both, and doubt not I ſhall be able to ſatisfy you.

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: I am not ſo ſoon ſatisfied, Sir.—

sp.speaker: C. Cam.
sp.p: This way, Sir, if you pleaſe.—

sp.speaker: Lom.
sp.p: My daughter or the borough, Sir, —take your choice—Sophy or Gluttonbury—mind, I ſtick to that.

div.head: SCENE II. Mrs. Mildmay's.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Well, Sift, and can you learn whether the ſtory Mr. Melmoth hath told Narciſſa be true.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: O lord, Madam, it is exactly as I gueſs'd yeſterday. What Mr. Melmoth told Narciſſa, Mr. Syllogiſm told me; but I knew it was a ſib the moment I heard it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: But how are you aſſur'd of it today!

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: From colonel Camply's own mouth, madam; who call'd me into the parlour this morning, and began to catechiſe me like a ſchool-maſter. Mrs. Sift, ſays he, what makes you abroad ſo early? What, your ladies have ſent you out upon the enquiry, I ſuppoſe, I know they are curious and inquiſitive.—Indeed, Sir, ſays I, you know no lady in our houſe half ſo inquiſitive as myſelf. Well, ſays he, what's the news then, at home? Why, Sir, ſays I, we hear that Mr. Melmoth's father is dead, and has diſinherited him.— Diſinherited him! ſays he, an idle ſtory, Sift, an idle ſtory, there is nothing in it.—So I thought, an pleaſe your honour, ſaid I, for I underſtood Mr. Melmoth was ſon to the ſtrange gentleman who viſited you yeſterday. Ay, Sift, ſays he, while that gentleman lives, Mr. Melmoth's fortunes are in the hands of a father.—Oh, ma'am, I'm poſitively certain it is as I firſt ſuggeſted.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Then ſo far all is well; but did you learn nothing more?

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Oh, yes, ma'am; you wanted to know if the gentleman was married or not: but that ſeems to be a doubt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: A doubt! Did colonel Camply ſay it was a doubt!

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: No; madam, I did not think that a proper queſtion to put to the colonel. But Mrs. Tiptoe, his honour's houſe-keeper, with whom I had a little confab afterwards, over-heard the gentleman tell her maſter yeſterday that he was married.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: How then is it a doubt?— [aſide] Oh no! my fears are true, and I muſt ſtill be wretched.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Why, it ſeems, madam, the gentleman has loſt his wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Loſt her! How?

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: Nay, ma'am, I know nothing more than that he can't find her; ſo that at leaſt ſhe is loſt to him. He has not ſeen her, I find, theſe twelve years paſt though, by his own account, which is a little extraordinary, he has been looking for her almoſt from one end of the world to the other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Good heavens! my hopes revive.

sp.speaker: Sift.
sp.p: The colonel, adviſes him, if he don't find her ſoon, to look out for another: but he is one of your conſtant ſwains it ſeems; and declares, that if his firſt love cannot be found, ſhe ſhall certainly be his laſt.— Whether the gentleman will keep his word or not, is another affair. But this is all I could learn of the matter, madam, as it ſtands at preſent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied. [aſide.] Is he then true to one he thought unfaithful? and can he ſtill remember me with tenderneſs? [to Sift.] Go, leave me, Sift; I ſee Narciſſa coming.—

div.p: Well, Narciſſa, I hope, that, on reflection, you are convinc'd of the danger and impropriety of your behaviour. Think, my dear, into what frightful perils your indiſcretion had betray'd you. Believe me, child, ſuch unadvis'd proceeding, differs little from wilful diſobedience.—

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Indeed, madam, I ſhudder at the reflection, and am hardly recover'd from the terrour into which your relation had thrown me.—But, with regard to Mr. Melmoth's affinity, how was it poſſible for me, to have any ſuſpicion of it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: It certainly was not: but, in a matter of ſo much importance, you ſhould not have acted ſo precipitately.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Nor ſhould I, mama, had not you been ſo much on the reſerve, and ſpoken of Mr. Melmoth ſo diſreſpectfully yeſterday morning.—But, for the future, I am all obedience.—How would you have me behave to him now?—as you ſaid ſo little to him laſt night, he will undoubtedly make me a viſit this morning. —How am I to reſiſt his ſolicitations, without giving him my reaſons for it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Cannot you turn the converſation on another ſubject? I ſhall now very ſoon come to an explanation with your father.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: My father! madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Yes, Narciſſa, that long-loſt father, whom you have heard me ſo often lament, is now in Bath. I ſaw him yeſterday by accident, and to-day intend to procure an interview; which ſhould have been over, before I had imparted this circumſtance, had not your laſt night's adventure anticipated the diſcovery of Mr. Melmoth's being your brother.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: But, is it not ſtrange, madam, that he ſhould ſay nothing to me of his father's arrival? But, on the contrary, ſhould tell me he was dead, and had diſinherited him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: I cannot divine his reaſons for ſuch behaviour. But, men in love, Narciſſa, are ſtrange creatures. He might do it, poſſibly, to make a trial of your regard for him.—

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: It muſt have been a ſcheme ſure to miſlead me into that dangerous project of elopement, which might have prov'd ſo fatal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: It might be ſo; and therefore it would not be amiſs, my dear, if you affect to reſent it as ſuch; nay, I would have yon do it, were it only to give a preparatory check to his paſſion, before he knows that you're his ſiſter. It will be improper for me to ſee him yet, as well in regard to what has paſs'd, as to the danger of betraying a mother's affection too ſoon. I muſt ſpeak firſt with your father.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: In what a ſituation then, madam, do you leave your Narciſſa? Is it for me to act ſo hard a part? Can I affect to treat with diſregard, the man ſo late I lov'd? Alas! I find his image wanting here. The. void it left, no brother can ſupply.—Oh! my poor heart!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: I ſhare, my dear Narciſſa, your diſtreſs; and would not taſk you with a mother's weakneſs, But, for this once, call up your reſolution: an explanation yet were premature.—But here he comes—I muſt retire.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Then let my duty teach me to diſſemble.

div.stage: (As he enters) Narciſſa! and alone! I feared this happineſs had been denied me.—My dear, Narciſſa! I am glad to ſee you look ſo charmingly to-day.—I was afraid, the ill ſucceſs of our laſt night's adventure, might have had an effect upon your ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.stage: [In a trembling voice, being greatly diſturbed.]
sp.p: Not at all, Sir, I never was in better ſpirit in my life.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Indeed! I wiſh I could ſay ſo—but our unlucky diſappointment!

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Unlucky!

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Cruelly ſo: we might, ere this, have been half-way on our journey; and, in a few hours more, at the end of it;—where we might have put it out of the power of accident to part us.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: For that very reaſon, Mr. Melmoth, may it not be as well we were prevented?—What! to be tied together for life! never to be parted! Might we not, in time, have been tir'd of one another; and, after that, have been moſt diſagreeable companions?

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Glad we were prevented! tir'd of one another! diſagreeable companions! How different is this language, and this behaviour, Narciſſa, to that of yeſterday?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: What if I ſhould have chang'd my mind ſince yeſterday, Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Chang'd your mind, Narciſſa!

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Is it impoſſible, Sir?—Did you never hear of a woman's changing her mind?

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Yes, madam, I have heard of wonderful changes in women's minds:—but you are not in earneſt, Narciſſa?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I am at preſent in no diſpoſition for jeſting.—
sp.stage: [Very gravely and confuſed, as through the whole ſcene.]

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: And you are really glad we were prevented going to Scotland to be married? Surely you diſſemble with me?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Not in that, believe me, Sir.—I would not have gone off with you to Scotland, and been married to you, for the world.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Nay, then there is a change indeed.—But, for heaven's ſake, why? What can have work'd this aſtoniſhing alteration? What have I done, or ſaid, or thought? How am I chang'd, that ſuch a change ſhould have happened in you? Some villain, envious of my happineſs, muſt have unjuſtly traduc'd, and blacken'd my reputation.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p:
Why, ſomething has been ſaid of you, it muſt be confeſs'd. But it was ſo far from being to your diſadvantage, that, had I never had any knowledge of you before, it would have induc'd me to love and eſteem you as a brother.—But, with regard to your own behaviour to me, Mr. Melmoth, I
muſt own it has been very exceptionable. How could you tell me, Sir, that your father was dead?

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: He is, Narciſſa.—

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Mr. Melmoth.—I am well aſſur'd your father is ſtill living; and, muſt freely declare, that were there not another man in the world, I would not give my hand to his ſon.— [aſide, burſting into tears.] —Now, I hope, my mama will be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Do I live? Am I awake?— [looking after her with aſtoniſhment.]—Was that Narciſſa? or am I Frederic Melmoth? What can be the meaning of all this?—If ſhe be loſt, I know at leaſt who to thank for it.—Lord Courtly ſhall pay dear for this officiouſneſs. —I muſt and will have this behaviour explained.

div.head: SCENE III. Another apartment in the ſame houſe.
div.stage: Enter General Melmoth, ſhewn in by a ſervant,

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Pleaſe to walk this way, Sir.—Mrs. Mildmay deſires to be at preſent excus'd; but my young miſtreſs will wait on you immediately.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Madam, your moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: —Another painful taſk! Is this my father? certainly it is—he ſtrikes me with an awe I never felt before.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: I am ſorry, madam, I cannot have the pleaſure of ſeeing Mrs. Mildmay.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.stage:
[Heſitating and confuſed, as thro' the whole of this ſcen •
▪
sp.p: You have then buſineſs with my mama, Sir.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: I have, madam; but, as you are principally concerned in it, I ſhall, with your leave, impart it to you.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: If it be of immediate conſequencc, Sir— otherwiſe I ſhould rather—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Nay, but young lady, it is of conſequence, and to you too: I am not to learn, with regard to your late generous behaviour to Mr. Melmoth.—I am a relation of his; and, apprehending your laſt night's diſappointment might have ſome diſagreeable conſequences, which I am able to remove, I have taken the liberty of the preſent intruſion.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: This openneſs of behaviour on your part, Sir, would be a reproach to any mean reſerve on mine. But I am only at liberty to ſay, that the diſappointment, as you call it, was a fortunate one.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Is it poſſible you can think ſo? Then muſt I have been miſinform'd.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: You will excuſe me, Sir; but my mama hath fully convinc'd me, that my intended marriage with Mr. Melmoth, would have been highly improper.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Improper!

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Dreadful!—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me, madam.—Dreadful! What new folly hath he committed, then? to what baſeneſs deſcended, that ſhould make an alliance with him deſerving ſuch an epithet?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Don't miſtake me, Sir;—I have ſtill the higheſt eſteem for Mr. Melmoth; but my mama—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Objects to his want of fortune; I know it. But if I convince her ſhe is miſtaken.—

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Yet even then, Sir, notwithſtanding the ſincere regard I ſtill entertain for Mr. Melmoth, and the great reſpect which, though a ſtranger, I feel for yon, I could not be induc'd to liſten to the ſolicitations of either.—No, Sir, I never can marry any man who calls you father.—But I can explain myſelf no farther. My mama is, by this time, diſengag'd, and will herſelf attend you.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p:
What is all this? Reſpect for me!—not marry any man who calls me father!—I am not young
Melmoth's father; and if I were, what then?—unleſs —but here comes the mother; ſhe may ſpeak more plainly.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Mildmay. [Who ſtands at a diſtance, and looks at him with tenderneſs.]
div.p: I beg pardon, madam, but— [bowing ceremoniouſly, and advancing, 'till looking full in her face, he retreats ſlowly back.] Sure—that face—I—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Mr. Wildman!

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Her voice too!—Gracious powers!—It is —'tis ſhe—it is—it is—my wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Yes; I am your wife, your once beloved wife.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: And ſtill belov'd!—Come to my arms, thou long-loſt, injur'd woman.— [they meet and embrace.] Oh, my wife!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: And art thou ſtill my husband?—I thought thou hadſt forgotten me.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Forgotten thee! Oh, never, never.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mid.
sp.p: Haſt thou forgiven me too?—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Forgiven thee, love!—Why, thou didſt never wrong me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Indeed, I did not; even when you thought me guilty, I was innocent.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: I know thou waſt; and 'tis in knowing that, that I've ſo long been wretched.—Yes, thou waſt innocent; but it was I, 'twas I, forgot the father and the huſband, and wrong'd both thee and thine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Yet, I was indiſcreet, and much to blame.

sp.speaker: G. M.
sp.p: Idle recrimination! no; you never were to blame—and yet, your name is Mildmay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p:
Nay, turn not from me—I perceive your doubts; but they are vain and groundleſs; my name's aſſum'd like thine.—For your embraces
form'd, and yours alone, theſe have been widow'd arms e'er ſince you leſt me.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: My faithful wife! Come then again to mine, and dwell for ever there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Alas, my love, this meeting's like a viſion. You ſeem as one new riſen from the dead.—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: 'Tis the re-union of departed ſouls, favour'd by heav'n to meet again above, with joy unutterable.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Oh! let us, then, thank heav'n for ſuch a meeting.—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: I cannot thank it better than I do. Heav'n knows the heart; and, from the fulneſs of my preſent joy, ſees mine o'erflow with gratitude.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Narciſſa, come, and take a father's bleſſing.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Is this my daughter too!

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Oh! my father.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: I will, but need not, bleſs thee. Heaven hath been ſo much kinder to thee than thy father.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Welcome, my Frederic, to a mother's arms.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Do you, then, give your daughter to my wiſhes? Thus let me thank you for the precious gift. — [Kneeling, and kiſſing Mrs. Midmay's hand; then riſing and turning to Narciſſa.]—But will Narciſſa ratify the grant?

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Indeed, brother— I know not what to ſay.—

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Brother! Narciſſa!

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Whence this miſtake?— [to Mrs. Mildmay.] We have alas! no ſon: our Frederic died, poor boy, long ſince, in India.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild
sp.p: Then have my hopes and fears alike been fruitleſs.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.stage: [Aſide, in a tone of joy and ſurprize.]
sp.p: —Again I feel my ſwelling heart replete.—

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: How! what!

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: And you are not my brother then at laſt?

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Your brother, Narciſſa! No; dear as I might love a ſiſter, I would not be your brother for the world. I ſee through the whole of your ſtrange behaviour now.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: —This young gentleman, my dear, is ſon to a diſtant relation lately dead: to whoſe fortune he is heir, and to whoſe laſt will I am executor.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Hoity toity! here's a tangled ſkain unravell'd.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: —And general Melmoth is Narciſſa's father!

div.stage: Enter lord Courtly, introduc'd by ſervant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Lord Courtly, madam.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ladies and gentlemen your ſervant. Happily aſſembled, I hope.—[turning to Young Melmoth.]— I preſume, Mr. Melmoth is, by this time, convinc'd of the impropriety of the angry billet he ſent me this morning.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: The miſtake we both lay under, my lord, at once juſtifies your behaviour and my reſentment.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Fortunately for me, however, that miſtake drew a promiſe from the amiable Narciſſa; which, I flatter myſelf, ſhe is too generous to forget.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: It is true, my lord, I did promiſe to give you my hand, if Mr. Melmoth could not accept it: and, if you had come ſome few minutes ago, I ſhould have been terribly puzzl'd what to ſay to you. But I can now keep my word, without your reaping any advantage from my promiſe.—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Madam! Mrs. Mildmay, what have I to hope?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: Indeed, my lord, my preſent perplexity of joy and ſurprize, makes me as incapable of expreſſing my obligations, as the event puts it out of my power to requite them. Narciſſa is not Mr. Melmoth's ſiſter; but, inſtead of a brother, ſhe hath found a father, and I a huſband; to whoſe guidance and protection we now are ſubject.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: With your leave then, madam, Mr. Melmoth ſhall be yet your ſon.

sp.speaker: Y. Mel.
sp.p: Then have I found, inſtead of loſt, a father.
sp.stage: [Bowing to general Melmoth, who advances to embrace him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mild.
sp.p: As to the preference I once gave your lordſhip—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: It lays me under an obligation, madam, that, in the preſent circumſtances, makes all apology needleſs.

sp.speaker: Narc.
sp.p: Generouſly ſaid; is not it, Mr. Melmoth? —Indeed, my lord, I wiſh you a better wife than I ſhould have made you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And I you, madam, all happineſs, with a huſband that deſerves you.

sp.speaker: T. Mel.
sp.p: I ſhall endeavour to merit the compliment, my lord.

div.stage: Enter alderman Lombard, colonel Camply and Sophia.

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: Your ſervant, gentlemen and ladies. You ſeem to be mighty well pleas'd here: my daughter Sophy and the colonel have let me a little into ſomething—

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Oh, Camply! oh, my friend, behold my injur'd, much-wrong'd wife and daughter!

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Is it poſſible!

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: How, how! the widow Mildmay general Melmoth's wife!

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: I ſee you're fill'd with wonder! I could indeed, relate a tale moſt wonderful, but that exceſs of joy prevents its utterance.

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: Well then, we'll wait, general, 'till you are a little more ſorrowful.—In the mean time, I muſt inform you, that I have ſettled matters with your friend Camply.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: I am glad of it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lomb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, my daughter and the borough go together. There, take her, colonel; and make her juſt as good a huſband as ſhe proves a wife—for my own part, I ſhall defer my matrimonial project to another opportunity: and, I think, it would not be amiſs if his lordſhip follows my example.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sir, I hope I ſhall always have generoſity of temper enough, to rejoice in the happineſs of others, though not directly conducive to my own.

sp.speaker: G. Mel.
sp.p: Such a diſpoſition, my lord, cannot go long unrewarded. Your lordſhip will do me honour in permitting me to cultivate a farther acquaintance with it. But, from the events of to-day, we may ſee how ineffectual are all attempts to ſeparate thoſe whom love hath united, and heaven preſerv'd for each other.

sp.l: WHene'er phyſicians wrangle with each other,
And college-dons ſhut out each licens'd brother,
Should they throw ſquibs, made up of Latin ſcraps,
And come to pulling wigs, as women caps,
The ſick grow well, —Death will not lay about him;
He has more honour than to work without 'em.
Should you [to the pit] whoſe ſkill and wiſdom we acknowledge,
The fellows of this old dramatic college,
(No matter what the cauſe of diſputation,)
Crowd hither ev'ry night for altercation;
The Bard, half dead before, enjoys the ſport,
Gets ſtrength each day, and is the better for't.
Warm'd with this ſubject, let your fancies play,
And me, by licence, make a Doctor, pray;
Suppoſe this gown, a ſuit of velvet, plain,
With a gold button, and this fan a cane;
My cap a formal tye, moſt wiſely big,
O, no—I had forgot—a ſmart bag wig:
No phyſic-buſhes now are ſeen in town;
For all the ſigns, you know, are taken down;
Call me licentiate, fellow, what you will,
I'll feel your pulſes all, —and prove my ſkill.
The pulſes of the boxes firſt I feel, —
And by their beating will their thoughts reveal; [She acts the doctor feeling a pulſe.
Languid and low—Wildman's old faſhion'd ſtory
Was much too nervous, to be ſet before ye.
For twelve long years, a tender wife forſaking,
Worn out with wand'ring, and what's worſe, with raking:
Then to return, —He was not worth the taking.
As for the pulſes of my friends above—
They thump for joy—when ſpouſes kiſs and love.—
Bleſs their young hearts, —what means this palpitation!
Each miſs's blood is now in agitation!
Each quick pulſation for Narciſſa beats;
When ſhe went off—they ſcarce could keep their ſeats.
When Lombard talk'd of bribes, —how felt you that? [To the pit
Some pulſes in this houſe went pat, pat, pat.
If this our night's preſcription you have taken,
Without wry faces, or your heads much ſhaken;
If you perceive ſome character, ſome wit,
With plot and humour—quantum ſufficit;
Mix'd up with ſal-volatile of ſatire;
Let it—quotidie nocte repetatur.—
'Tis by our noſtrums you are kept alive:
Purſue the regimen of doctor CLIVE.
